SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Follow-up of chronic problems. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Mr. Brian Smith is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow- up of his Chronic problems. It has been a little while since I have seen the patient. The patient reports he just feels out of sorts lately. He does not know if it is the change in the seasons or if he is just doing a lot of projects around the house and doing some construction on his own. He notes he is tired and fatigued. He reports feeling bloated every once in a while. He denies any fevers, chills, or weight loss. Mr. Smith does report some lightheadedness. He endorses some fine crackles at the bases of his Lungs, and 1+ pitting edema in his lower extremities. He has a slight cough. He states he is not sure if it's just the change of seasons and he is getting a cold. He continues to take his medications. Regarding his diet, he has been watching his diet. It was hard to cook or prepare meals so he ate out a lot, and not always the best food out. He is continuing to monitor his blood pressure at home, and report them to me in the patient portal if they are getting elevated. He will continue to take lisinopril 20 mg a day. He should continue to weigh himself every day, and he will call me if he gains more weight. Thepatient denies any other symptoms of shortness of breath. He Endorses slight chest pain and slight cramps that seem to go away after about an hour after he first feels it. Mr.'s cough is mild. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 • Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion. • Respiratory: Endorses cough. • Musculoskeletal: endorses lower extremity edema. • Integumentary: • Neurological: • Psychiatric: • 

VITALS

 • Blood Pressure: Elevated. 

EXAM

 The patient will follow up with me in 1 week for follow up. I will prescribe Lasix 80 mg once a day, as noted above. All questions were answered.

 Right knee pain.

She has been putting ice on it and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help. She describes where the pain is and where it is mostly located: right on the inside of her knee. She denies any other pain down here in her calves. 

EXAM

 Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial portion of the knee and the medial meniscus area. There is no pain with flexion or flexion of the ankle. No tenderness with valgus stressing. Tenderness to palpation of the bilateral lower extremities. 

RESULTS

 Right knee strain.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Back pain. 

MEDICAL HISTORY

 The patient is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, osteoarthritis, and hypertension, who presents today with some back pain. The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes a little too quickly. He believes he has a lumbar strain from the lifting. He states he thought he heard a pop at the time, but it did not relieve the pain. He notes he had to lie down for approximately hour before it relieved his pain. His back has been a little stiff ever since. He has taken Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat on the spot but it does not seem to help. He denies any numbness or tingling in his legs. Regarding his diabetes, he states it has been under control for the most part. He reports he is good about monitoring his blood pressure readings at home, but on the weekends he tends to forget. He endorses that his diet has been less than stellar and states he needs to go clean for a couple of weeks. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 • Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or changes in appetite. • Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower back and knee pain. 

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

 • Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. • Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. • Gastrointestinal: No hematochezia, melena. • Genitourinary: Positive straight leg raise. 

VITALS REVIEWED

 • Blood Pressure: Elevated. 

RESULTS

 Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 Mr. logs back pain and hypertension. • Medical Reasoning: He reports back pain while lifting boxes and having pain with flexion and extension of the back. • Additional Testing: We will order an MRI of his lower back for further evaluation. • Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged him to continue to ice his back. I also advised him to avoid any strenuous activity and we will refer him to physical therapy. • medical Treatment: Prescription for meloxicam 15 mg once a day is provided. • Diabetes: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice a day. Repeat hemoglobin a1c in 6 months. Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow-up in 2 months.

He notes that he is exercising a lot. His breathing function has been fine. He endorses some nasal congestion from the pollen but denies any shortness of breath. Regarding his hypertension, he has done a great job of keeping it controlled. He states that he does not run on the weekends. He continues to take Prozac 20 mg daily. The Patient denies any issues with shortNESS of breath with exertion.

She states that she has not been taking it as much on the weekend. • Additional Testing: We will order an echoccardogram for her. • Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue her routine blood work. • medical Treatment: Continue with Prozac 10 mg daily as is. Prescription for Norvasc 10 mg weekly provided. Hypertension. •Medical Reasonings: She has been compliant with her medications and has been asymptomatic for the past several years. CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Iron deficiency anemia. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Christina cooper is a 65-year-old female who was referred by Diane Nelson for a long-standing iron deficiencyanemia. She was diagnosed with iron deficiencyAnemia in 12/2019. Her followup blood work on 01/20/20 was revealed a low hemoglobin, stable hematocrit, and normal iron labs, although ferritin was low. She had a hysterectomy in 1996. Her last colonoscopy was approximately 5 to 6 years ago. She did not have any polyps at that time. Ms. cooper has been taking ferrous sulfate, 500 mg by mouth, for approximately 1 year. She has been feeling fatigued often during the day and even feverish with chills at times. When she tries to be active, she feels like she can't catch her breath and she sounds like she is wheezing. She also has been experiencing some headaches which are not like her. She denies any issue with sedation in the past. She is taking iron pills, 25 mg twice daily, over the counter. She does not have a pacemaker or defibrillator, or use oxygen at night. She only drinks alcohol once or twice a year. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 • Constitutional: Denies sleep apnea or dyspnea on oxygen. • Musculoskeletal: Endorses tenderness to palpation of the bilateral lower extremities. Endorses chills. • Integumentary: • Neurological: Endorse headaches. 

EXAM

 The patient will follow up with me in 10 years for her follow-up bloodwork. I have asked her to continue each dose with vitamin C found in orange juice for the next 12 weeks. We will then recheck her iron levels, iron, B12, and folate. If her blood work is normal, we will consider a capsule endoscopy. If this is inconclusive, we may need to consider an Egd and a colonoscopic to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. • Additional Testing: We will order an EDS, colonoscopies, and a Capsule Endoscopy of the upper extremity. • Medical Treatment: She will start taking Iron pills with orange juice, twice daily. Repeat iron exams in 8-12 weeks. Referral to hematologist provided. Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. Call us if she has any questions or worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Newly diagnosed pituitary adenoma. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents in consultation at the request of his primary care provider on 03/1/21 for worsening headaches. The patient presented to his primary Care provider, Dr. howard, on 3/01/21 complaining of worsening headaches over the past few months. He denied any trouble with headaches in the past. The onset of his headaches began approximately 3 months ago and they have progressively worsened. He describes the pain as a dull, nagging ache behind the eyes. The pain usually occurs in the morning and lasts for a few hours. He denies fever, rashes, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, and passing out. He has never passed out. The headaches also tend to be worse in the evening. He tries taking Tylenol a few times for the headaches but it did not work and he stopped, so he stopped taking the medication. He rates his headaches as 6 out of 10 severity. He states the pain is located behind his eyes and that it feels like a dull ache. He does not have any pain in the upper extremities. He reports no headaches with vision loss, vision loss in the lower extremities, or balance issues. He notes that his eyes were checked in the fall and his vision was normal. Mr. Ward is employed as a computer programmer and has been married for 25 years. His past clinical history is unremarkable. He Denies any history of diseases. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 • Constitutional: Denies fever, fevers, or chills. • Neck: denies neck issues. • Neurological: Endorses numbness and tingling. • Musculoskeletal: endorses weakness and numbness. • Psychiatric: Endorse dyspnea. • 

VITALS REVIEWED

 • Eyes: Normal vision. • Sight: Bilateral bitemporal hemianopia. • Palpation: Normal color vision. 

RESULTS

 MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitARY lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size. No other abnormalities are noted. 

PAST HISTORY

 Medical Bilateral hypothyroidism. 

SOCIAL HISTORY

 Employed as computer programmer. Married for 25years. Denies previous clinical history. 

FAMILY HISTORY

 No known family history of disease. 

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

 Alcohol: No. Respiratory: No known allergies. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 Neurological - Examination of the right eye: Normal visual field test. Cranial nerves are equal and reactive. Sensation: No lower extremity nerve deficit. Normal motor movements. PITuitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH. Normal. 

ASSESSMENT

 Bilateral pituitaries are normal. 

PLAN

 After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. We discussed the nature of his diagnosis and that this appears to be a benign pituitsary adadenoma. Treatment options were discussed including surgical intervention and risk of anesthesia including but not limited to the risk of heart attack, stroke, and death. We also discussed the risks of infection, need for further surgery, wound issues such as spinal fluid leak or infection, which may require prolonged hospitalization or additional procedure. I recommended a transsphenoidal approach to do the surgery. This is minimally invasive and we go through the sphenoid sinus. I reviewed the labs dated 3/3/21 including CBC, Unes, coagulation, and crp. All were normal. Pituitary hormones were normal and all other results werenormal. I advised the patient that surgical intervention to excise and decompress thepituitary fossa is indicated. He is symptomatic with clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression. We reviewed the brain MRI and serology findings today and I have recommended that we proceed with surgical intervention. I also recommended that the patient be referred to the eye doctor for a full exam and they will do what's called a visualField test to map his peripheral vision or side vision prior to surgery. We will monitor after surgery to see if his vision is improving. The Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Smith-Magenis syndrome. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Katherine Allen is a 22-month-old female, a twin, who presents to the clinic today for screening of the kidneys by ultrasound. She is a well-nourished female who is slightly fussy when examined. She has mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. She used to only drink milk, but I took her off dairy milk and she is now drinking water. She still does not walk but is crawling and trying to take steps. She does have a GI doctor because she has reflexes really bad. She also had a dietician who told us to take her off cow's milk. She then saw an allergist, and also a neurologist, who diagnosed her with this syndrome. The family lives in Dallas, and she has seen an orthopedic and an ophthalmologist. She currently is in therapy, feeding therapy, occupational therapy, and physical therapy. She will start speech therapy in the next couple of weeks. She seems to pee a lot and it feels like she drinks a lot. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 • Musculoskeletal: Denies bilateral lower extremity edema. Endorses dyspnea on exertion. • Neurological: Endorses reflexes bad. 

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

 • Constitutional: Appropriate weight and height. • Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Normal. • Cardiovascular: No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. • Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. • Gastrointestinal: Bilateral wet diapers, 8 to 10 in a 24-hour period. Normal external female genitalia. 

RESULTS

 Kidney ultrasound, ordered and completed today. Follow-up should be at the town center location. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 Katherine Allenis syndrome, twin. • Medical Reasoning: The patient is a twin with Smith- Magenis Syndrome. Several organ systems can be affected by this chromosomal deletion syndrome. congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature. • Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the syndrome in detail today. I encouraged the patient to continue drinking water and limiting her intake of dairy milk. • Additional Testing: We are going to order a kidney ultrasound for further evaluation. • medical Treatment: We will refer her to a kidney specialist in Cheney,WI for further review. • Specialist Referrals: She will follow up with me in Cheney if her results are abnormal. Patient Agreements: the patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

This should also help with the swelling of the knee. He should also reduce his salt intake. We will continue to monitor his blood pressure, which is currently 130/70. I have explained to him that his x-rays did not reveal any fracture or ligamental abnormalities. We discussed treatment options for his current pain and I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively.  Follow-up during neo- agit chemotherapy.

She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule biopsy was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending at this time. The patient reports she has been going through a lot lately. She reports she just had her treatment. She has a minimal cough and a sore throat. She denies any shortness of breath. Regarding her sore throat, she notes it seems to be persistent. She does note it is dry and there is no mucus with it. She notes she is drinking lots of fluids and has been eating but not as much as she normally would. She endorses sore throat and mild fatigue. ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 1. Lungs. - Medical Reasoning: The patient's cough is likely due to her recent chemotherapy regimen. - Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the nature of the diagnosis, as well as her current regimen, in detail. Gastrointestinal, Genitourinary, and Genitouring: She will continue to take food and fluids, as needed, to prevent dehydration and any further Weight loss. CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Low immunoglobulin A level. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Kyle Allen is a pleasant 53-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of a low immunoglobe a level. The patient was referred by his primary care physician as he has been having problems getting frequent infections. He reports that he tends to get infections in the winter time as he is so used to it. He notes that he gets a lot of colds and they seem to linger for a long time. He denies any changes to his abdominal tract, but notes that some people may find that they get frequent respiratory tract or sinus or abdominal infections. This does not necessarily seem to be the case for him, but it can go along with other immunodeficiencies. He states that he has a history of type 2 diabetes and his family owns a donut shop down at the end of the street. He explains that this is probably part of the cause of his diabetes. He does admit to having tried to give blood but he did not qualify due to his recent trip to Zambia. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Musculoskeletal: No fever. Neurological: Denies changes in appetite. 

VITALS

 All vital signs are within the normal limits. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 CV: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs. RESPIRATORY: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. Neck: Neck is supple without any lymphadenopathy. 

RESULTS

 

PAST HISTORY

 Medical Type 2 diabetes. 

FAMILY HISTORY

 No family history of immune deficiencies. 

MEDICATIONS

 metformin. 

ASSESSMENT

 Bilateral lower extremity iga deficiency. 

PLAN

 After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. I have explained to him that his iga levels are normal and that this finding is common to him. We discussed that this deficiency may be associated with other antibodies and that we will order additional blood work that includes checking those other antibodies. I also advised him that if he does end up needing any blood products between now and when he sees me next, he should tell me that he had a historyof an igo deficiency. He was also advised that there is a risk that his body can strongly react to some blood products and he should be prepared. All questions were answered. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow up with me in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Right elbow pain. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Lawrence Smith is a pleasant 60-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow Pain. The onset of his pain began 1 week ago, however it has worsened over the past week. He denies any specific trauma. The patient describes his pain as being located in the inside of his right elbow and states that it is difficult for him to lift and do things because of the pain. He endorses that the pain keeps him up at night. He has tried ibuprofen, but it does not provide him with relief. Of note, he denies any history of a right elbow injury. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain, right forearm pain, and left wrist pain. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 MSK: Examination of the right elbow: Positive for pain to palpation. Mild tenderness of the medial epicondyle. 

RESULTS

 X-rays of theRight elbow, 2 views, obtained on today's visit show no fracture or bony abnormality. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 1. Right elbowPain, right elbow. 

PLAN

 After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained to him that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of any fracture or bone abnormity. I has recommended that we treat the patient conservatively with a long arm sling. He will follow up with me in 1 week to check on his progress. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow-up in 1 month.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Emergency department visit. 

MEDICAL HISTORY

 Patient reports history of hypertension. 

MEDICATIONS

 Patient reports taking Cozaar 100 mg daily, Norvasc 5 mg once daily. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain. Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath. Musculoskeletal: Reports lower extremity edema. 

VITALS

 Blood pressure: 128/72 mmHg. Heart: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. Lungs are clear bilaterally. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 Neck - General Examination: There is no jugular venous distention. Cardiovascular - Auscultation of Heart: Maintained preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, and mild rales. Gastrointestinal - Examination of Abdomen: Trace edema in the bilateral lower extremities. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 1. Hypertension, mild to moderate. - Medical Reasoning: The patient's elevated blood pressure in the office today was consistent with uncontrolled hypertension. His echocardiogram from the emergency department demonstrated preserved ejectION fraction of 50%, and normal diASTolic filling. - Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of dietary modification around the holidays. I encouraged the patient to continue taking his medication and to monitor his diet. He was provided with a blood pressure cuff that he can use at home. Questions were invited and answered today. Patient Agreements: The Patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Kidney stone. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Russell Russell is a pleasant 67-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right-sided pain in the right side of his abdomen below his ribs. The onset of his pain began several days ago, when he saw his primary care physician, who ordered a CT scan of the abdomen and told him that he had a kidney stone. He was referred to a urologist for further evaluation. The CT scan revealed a 5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. He denies any pain with urination or peeing, but notes that his urine looks a little dark sometimes. He does notice some burning when he urinates. The patient reports that he feels like he is unable to find a comfortable position. He has taken Tylenol, but it has not really helped. He reports no nausea, vomiting, or chills. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Musculoskeletal: Reports right- side pain. Neurological: Denies nausea or vomiting. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 GI/GU: No tenderness to palpation. No evidence of any rebound or guarding. No peritoneal signs. There is positive CVA tenderness on the right flank. 

ASSESSMENT

 Right kidney stone, acute nephrolithiasis. 

PLAN

 After reviewing the patient's examination and CT results today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him in regards to his current symptoms. I have explained to him that his exam findings were likely caused by a renal stone. We discussed treatment options for this and I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively with oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. He should continue to alternate with Tylena. I will also prescribe a strainer that he can strain his urine so that we can see the stone when it passes. If his symptoms do not improve over the next week, we will discuss further treatment such as lithotripsy which is essentially a shock wave procedure in which we sedate him and use shock waves to break up the stone and help it pass. We could also do a ureTERoscopy which is a small telescope small camera used to go up to the urethra and bladder and up into the ureters to retrieve the stone. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow up with me in 1 to 2 weeks and if he is still symptomatic, we may need to consider further treatment including lithotRIpsy.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Right foot ulcer. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Nicholas Reyes is a pleasant 53-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcers. The onset of his symptoms began 6 days ago, when he noticed a foul smell in his socks. He later noticed that his dog was also smelling his socks a lot. He began to notice a necrotic wound on the heel of his foot, approximately 2 by 2 centimeters. He notes that it was stinging initially and that he had just done something small. He denies any pain at this time. At this time, he is on day 6 or 7 of a 10-day course of antibiotics. He reports that after he started the antibiotics, his foot started to feel pretty good. He noticed that it has turned black around the outside of the wound. He also noticed that there is a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle. He states that every time he pushes on the calf muscle, it is hard. He adds that he has had difficulty catching his breath when he is walking around the house. The patient also reports that his blood sugars have been trending in the 3 to 4 hundreds for the last 2 weeks. He is being closely watched. 

MEDICAL HISTORY

 The patient reports that he is a diabetic with a history of 6.7 an A1c. 

SOCIAL HISTORY

 Patient reports he likes to hike in the park. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Musculoskeletal: Reports right foot Ulcer. 

VITALS

 Slight fever. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 CV: Bilateral palpable pulses femorally and popliteal pulses are present. No palpable pulses dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial. MSK: Examination of the right foot: Necrosis of the plantar and dorsal aspects of the foot. Sloughing of the tissue as well as what looks like cellulitis around the area. erythemia. Slight itching. 

RESULTS

 X-ray of the Right foot was reviewed today and shows no evidence of osteomyelitis. 

ASSESSMENT

 1. Non- healing diabetic foot ulce. 

PLAN

 After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him in regards to his current symptoms. We discussed that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of osteopathy. I advised him that the x-ray revealed soft, mushy skin with some yellow drainage. He was advised that this was likely caused by his new shoes and that we should continue his antibiotics. I also recommended that we obtain a culture for further evaluation. He will continue his antibiotic therapy. We will likely extend or call in a new antibiotic depending on the culture. He should follow up with his endocrinologist in 7 days. 2. Diabetes type 2. 

PLAN

 We will continue to closely monitor his blood glucose levels. 3. Follow up with me in 7 Days. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow up in 7Days.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Right knee pain. 

MEDICAL HISTORY

 Patient reports history of hypertension and Lyme disease. 

MEDICATIONS

 Patient reports taking lisinopril, 2 mg twice daily, and metformin, 20 mg once daily. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Constitutional: Denies fever or chills. Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling. 

VITALS

 Blood pressure: 132/70 mmHg Heart rate: 62 bpm Lungs: clear to auscultation bilaterally 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 SKIN: Examination of the right knee shows erythema and edema as well as an area of fluctuance over the right patella. Pain to palpation of theRight anterior knee. Slight soreness. 

RESULTS

 Lyme titer: elevated. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 1. Lyme disease. - Medical Reasoning: The patient presents today with symptoms similar to Lyme Disease. He denies any other symptoms such as fever, chills, cough, shortness of breath, or dizziness. - Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the nature of the diagnosis and that this is typically treated with oral antibiotics. I advised the patient that sometimes this can lead to intravenous antibiotics. He was advised that it is not recommended to give antibiotics through the iv. - Additional Testing: We will order a lyme titer and a western blot to evaluate for Lyme disease, aswell as a lipid panel. 2. Hypertension. - medical Reasoning; The patient is doing well with his medication and his blood pressure is within the normal limits. He is also a avid hunter and has been doing a good job on the lisin Opril 20 mg twice a day. His blood sugar has been in the 1-20 range for the past 2 years. - patient Education and counseling: we discussed the importance of maintaining a healthy lifestyle. We also discussed that his blood sugar should be in the 0-20s on an daily basis. -medical Treatment: He will continue on lisinOpril 20mg once a day, as noted above. We will also continue him on Doxycycline 100 mg twicea day for approximately 3 weeks. 3. Hygiene: Patient reports that he is a hunter and does spend a lot of time out in the yard. He does admit to having a tick bite on his right knee, however, he denies any signs of Lyme disease at this time. Patient Agreements: the patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow up with me in 3 weeks to check on his progress.
